text: List the common multiples from 1 to 100 for each pair of numbers. Then find the least common multiple for each pair.
a. Find three pairs of numbers for which the least common multiple equals the product of the two numbers.

Possible answers: 3, 5; 8, 9; 7, 11. If the two numbers do not share any factors other than 1, their LCM will be the product of the two numbers. If students choose pairs of numbers that do not share any factors, their answers will be reasonable.
b. Look at the pairs of numbers you found in ACE 2a. What is true about all three pairs of numbers?
Find two pairs of numbers with the given number as their least common multiple.

The manager of a restaurant turns on the two neon signs at the same time. Both signs blink as they are turned on. One sign blinks every 9 seconds. The other sign blinks every 15 seconds. In how many seconds will they blink together again?
45 seconds, which is the LCM of 9 and 15.

The school cafeteria serves pizza every sixth day and applesauce every eighth day. Suppose that pizza and applesauce are both on today's menu. In how many days will they be together on the menu again?
Solve Hank's new cards for the Algebra Connections game.
a. The GCF of 27 and N is 27. What could N be?
b. The LCM of 27 and N is 27. What could N be?
List the common factors of each pair of numbers. Then find the greatest common factor of each pair.

Mr. Mendoza and his 23 students are planning to have hot dogs at their class picnic. He can buy hot dogs at their class picnic. He can buy hot dogs in packages of 12 and hot dog buns in packages of 8.

a. Mr. Mendoza wants everyone to get the same number of hot dogs and buns with no leftovers. What is the least number of packages of hot dogs and the least number of packages of buns Mr. Mendoza can buy? How many hot dogs and buns will each person get?
2 packages of hot dogs and 3 packages of buns; 1 hot dog and 1 bun.

b. Suppose that the class invites the principal, the secretary, the bus driver, and three parents to help out at the picnic. Mr. Mendoza still wants everyone to get the same number of hot dogs and buns with no leftovers. How many packages of hot dogs and buns will he need to buy now? How many hot dogs ad buns will each person get?

10 packages of hot dogs and 15 packages of buns; 4 hot dogs ad 4 buns.

120 is the LCM for 12, 8, and 30. That means they will need to purchase 10 packages of hot dog buns (10 × 12 =120) and 15 packages of hot dogs (15 × 8 = 120). 30 people will then each get an equal number of buns and dogs, 4.

The cast of a play had a party. The drama teacher served 20 veggie roll-ups and 40 carrot sticks as refreshments. Each cast member ate the same number of whole veggie roll-ups and the same number of whole carrot sticks. Nothing was left over. The drama teacher did not eat. How many cast memebers might have been at the party?

The common factors of 20 and 40 are 1, 2, 4, 5, 10, and 20. Therefore:

20 members; each member gets 1 veggie roll-up and 2 carrot sticks.

10 members; each member gets 2 veggie roll-ups and 4 carrot sticks.

5 members; each member gets 4 veggie roll-ups and 8 carrot sticks.

4 members; each member gets 5 veggie roll-ups and 10 carrot sticks.

2 members; each member gets 10 veggie roll- ups and 20 carrot sticks

1 members; the member gets all 20 veggie roll-ups and 40 carrot sticks.

Miriam's uncle donates 120 cans of juice and 90 packs of cheese crackers for a school picnic. Each students muct receive the same number of cans of juice and the same number of packs of crackers with no leftovers.
a. What is the greatest number of students who can come to the picnic and share the food equally? How many cans of juice and packs of crackers will each student receive? Explain.
The GCF of 120 and 90 is 30, so 30 students is the greatest number that can share the food equally; each student receives 4 cans of juice and 3 packs of crackers because 120 = 30 × 4 and 90 = 30 × 3.

b. Suppose Miriam's uncle eats two packs of crackers before he brings the supplies to school. What is the greatest number of students who can share the food equally? How many cans of juice and packs of crackers will each student receive? Explain.

There are now only 88 packs of cheese crackers. The GCF of 120 and 88 is 8. Therefore, 8 students can share the snacks equally; each student receives 15 cans of juice and 11 packs of crackers because 120 = 8 × 15 and 88 = 8 × 11.
The greatest common factor of a number n and 6 is 3. What are all the possible whole-number values for n?
• Find a number that satisfies the given condition.
a. forms a factor pair with 12 to give 48
b. forms a factor pair with 3 to give 48
c. forms a factor pair with 6 to give 48
d. forms a factor pair with 11 to give 121
Use the fact that 135 × 37 = 4,995 to find the value of 1,350 × 3,700.

4,995,000; multiply 4,995 by 1,000 for the three factors of 10. In the second expression, 135 is 10 times larger, and 37 is 100 times larger. Because of this, the product will need to be 1,000 times larger. When talking with students, avoid saying "just add three zeros," as this leads to misconceptions.
Put the factors of 30 and the factors of 36 onto a Venn diagram.
a. What do the numbers in the intersection (the "overlap") of the circular regions have in common?
They are common factors of both 30 and 36 (also factors of 6).
b. Explain how you can use your diagram to find the greatest common fator of 30 and 36. What is this greatest common factor?
The numbers in the intersection are 1, 2, 3, and 6. The greatest of these is 6, so 6 is the GCF of 30 and 36.
c. What is the least number that falls in the intersection?
The lowest common factor is 1. 1 is a factor of all whole numbers, so it is in the intersection of Venn diagrams for factors.
Use the terms factor, divisor, multiple, product, and divisible by to write as many statements as you can about the number sentence 7 × 9 = 63.

7 is a factor of 63. 9 is a factor of 63. 7 is a divisor of 63. 9 is a divisor of 63. 63 is a multiple of 7. 63 is a multiple of 9. The product of 7 and 9 is 63. 63 is divisible by 7. 63 is divisible by 9.
Use as many of the words prime, composite, and square as you can to describe each number.
Put the multiples of 5 and the multiples of 4 that are less than or equal to 40 onto a Venn diagram.

The multiples of 5 up to 40 are 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, and 40.

The multiples of 4 up to 40 are 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 28, 32, 36, and 40
a. What do the numbers in the intersection have in common?
b. Explain how you can use your diagram to find the least common multiple pf 5 and 4. What is this least common multiple?
The least number in the intersection is 20. So 20 is the LCM of 5 and 4.
c. Suppose numbers greater than 40 are allowed. List five more numbers that would be in the intersection. If you could use any number, what would be the greatest possible number in the intersection?
60, 80, 100, 120, 140, 160, etc. These numbers are all multiples of the LCM, which is 20. There is no greatest common multiple.
a. Suppose a jet travels 60 kilometers in 5 minutes. How many kilometers will it travel in 2 hours? In 6 hours?

If the jet travel 60 km in 5 minutes, it travels 12 km per minute. This unit rate helps to calculate the distance when given any amount of time. 12 × 2 × 60 = 1,440 kilometers. In 6 hours, the jet will travel 1,440 × 3 = 4,320 kilometers.
b. How many more kilometers will the jet travel in 6 hours than in 2 hours?
In 6 hours, the jet will travel 4,320 - 1,440 = 2,880 kilometers more than in 2 hours.
c. If a trip takes 4 hours, how many kilometers does the jet travel?
In 4 hours, the jet would travel twice as many miles as in 2 hours, or 2,80 kilometers.
3 × 5 × 7 = 105. Use this fact to find each product.
9 × 5 × 7 will be 3 times as great as 3 × 5 × 7, or 315.
3 × 5 × 14 will be twice as great at 3 × 5 × 7, or 210.
3 × 50 × 7 will be 10 times as great as 3 × 5 × 7, or 1,050.
3 × 25 × 7 will be 5 times as great as 3 × 5 × 7, or 525
Hank added these cards to the Algebra Connections game. Solve each card for N.

Since 15 = 3 × 5, N might be any multiple pf 5 that is not also a multiple of 3.

Examples include 5, 10, 20, 25, 35, etc.

Students might guess and check to find possibilities.

Since 30 = 6 × 5, N might be a multiple of 6 that is not also a multiple of 5.

Examples include, 6, 12, 18, 24, 36, 42, 48, etc.

Students might guess and check to find possibilities.

Find a set of numbers that satisfy the conditions.

a. The LCM of two numbers is a square number.

2 and 4; LCM = 4

8 and 16; LCM = 16

These are two possible pairs, bu t accept any pairs that satisfy the conditions.
b. The LCM of three different numbers is 24.

Chinua and his friends practice multiplying by using dominoes. Each half of a domino has dots on it. The number of dots ranges from 0 to 6. The students use the two numbers on a domino as factors.

For the domino shown, Chinua would say "12."
a. What is the greatest product you can make from numbers on dominoes?
b. What is the least product you can make from numbers on dominoes?
c. Since there are seven different numbers (0-6) that can occur on each half of the domino, Chinua reasons that he needs to know 49 different products. This is too many. What did he forget?

Chinua forgot that multiplication is commutative, e.g., 3 × 4 = 4 × 3. He only needs to know 28 different products. Also, zero times anything is zero, and 13 of the 49 computations involve zero as a factor. (Note: There are only 19 different answers possible using two factors from 0 through 6.)

Ms. Santiago has many pens in her desk drawer. She says that if you divide the total number of pens by 2, 3, 4, 5, or 6, you get a remainder of 1. What is the least number of pens that could be in Ms. Santiago's drawer?
3 × 4 × 5 + 1 = 61 (Find the LCM of 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6, and add 1.)

a. Suppose there are 12- year cicadas and that cicadas have predators with 2-year cycles. How often would 12-year cicadas face their predators? Would life be better for 13-year cicadas than for 12-year cicadas? Explain.

12- year cicadas would meet 2- year predators eaither every time they emerge or never. The 13- year cicadas would encounter the predators every other time they emerge, so they could be better or worse off depending on whether the predator came out on odd or even years.

b. Suppose that 12-year and 13- year cicadas have predators with both 2-year and 3-year cycles. Suppose that both kinds of cicadas and both kinds of predators came up this year. When would the 12-year cicadas again have to face both kinds of predators at the same time? When would the 13-year cicadas face both? Which type of cicada do you think is better off?

The 12-year cicadas would meet one or both type of predators every time they emerge. The 13-year cicadas would meet the 2-year predators every other time they emerge and the 3-year predators every third time they emerge. This means that it would be 6 cycles, or 78 years, before the 13-year cicadas would have to face both predators again. They are better off than the 12-year cicadas.

Determine whether each statement is always, sometimes, or never true. Justify your answer.

a. The least common multiple of any number n and 1 is n.

Always true; the multiples of n are n × 1, n × 2, n × 3. The multiples of 1 are 1 × 1, 1 × 2, 1 × 3, ..., 1 × n,... Therefore, LCM(n, 1) = n. If students so not use this logice, they may guess and check several pairs of numbers to get to the same conclusion.
b. For any number n greater than 1, the least common multiple of n and itself is n × n.
Never true; the LCM of any number n greater than 1 and itself is n. Note that the statement is true for n = 1
• c. The least common multiple of any number n and 3 is 3n.
Sometimes true; it is only true whe the number doesn't have 3 as a factor.
d. The least common multiple of any primer number p and 1 is p.
Always true; the multiples of p × 1, p × 2, p × 3. The multiples of 1 are 1 × 1, 1 × 2, 1 × 3, ..., 1 × p, ... Therefore, LCM(p, 1) = p
Hank added these cards to the Algebra Connections game. Solve each card for N.

5 and N must share a factor.

Answers include:

10, LCM of 5 and 10 is 10.

5N = 50

20, LCM of 5 and 20 is 20

5N = 100

etc.

No possible answers.

Multiples of 5 are 5, 10, 15, 20, ...

None of these are less than 5N.

The LCM of two numbers will always be at most their product. Since the product of two numbers is 5N, it would be impossible to have an LCM greater than 5N.

N is a number that is relatively prime to 5.

That is, N is a number that is not divisible by 5.

Possible answers for N include 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8, 9, 11, 12, 13, 14, 16, 17, 18, 19, etc. For the LCM to be equal to the product of two numbers, the numbers cannot share any factors other than 1.

What is the mystery number pair? Use all four clues to determine your final solution.

Clue 1. The greatest common factor of the mystery pair is 7.

Clue 2. The least common multiple of the mystery pair is 70.

Clue 3. Each of the numbers in the mystery pair has two digits

Clue 4. One of the numbers in the mystery pair is odd. The other number is even.

What is my number? Use all three clues to determine your final solution.

Clue 1. My number is a multiple of 2 and 5.
Clue 2. My number is greater than 10 but less than 50.
Clue 3. The number 3 is a factor of my number.

Find a set of numbers that satisfies the conditions.

a. The GCF of two numbers is prime. The LCM of the two numbers is composite.
b. The GCF of two numbers is a square number.
c. The GCF and LCM of two numbers are equal.
d. The GCF of two numbers is 12. The LCM of the two numbers is 72.
e. The GCF of three different numbers is 5.
f. The GCF of four different numbers is 1.
a. Make up a word problem that you can solve by finding common factors.
b. Make up a different word problem that you can solve bu finding common multiples.
c. Solve your problems from ACE 30a and 30b. Explain how you know that your answers are correct.
